turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Help your mother find the bullet.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: There it is.  Give it to me.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: How do I load?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Load it for her.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: All right!  Am I exceedingly dangerous now?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: The National Safety Council would be appalled.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Then listen to me.  You're both disgusting--with your pride, your pride.  I hate you for coming here--like a federal marshal in a western film. I loved you when you stayed away. But here you are now--high noon in the Superbowl!  You fool, you fool.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: She's right, Norbert--go home. WOODLY I haven't said all I have to say.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Out!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Give me that Goddamn thing!  Now get out of here, or I might kill you.  Who knows?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You've killed women?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Seventeen of them--eleven by accident.  March!  Move!  You, too!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Norbert--you come, too.  Let him go, Harold.  Let him go.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Of course he can go--if he'll just go down on his hands and knees for a moment--and promise me that he does not find me comical in the least degree.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Do it, Norbert.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Ooops.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Ooops.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Can I--uh--help you gentlemen?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Gentlemen--that's nice.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: You startled me.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: The door ws unlocked.  Is it always unlocked?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: It's always locked.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: But here you are inside, aren't you?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: You're--you're old friends of Harold Ryan?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: We tried to be.  We tried to be.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: He's dead, you know.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Dead!  Such a final word.  Dead!  Did you hear that?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Hello?  Oh--hello, Mother.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Hello, Mother.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: ...Who?... Did she say how far apart the pains were?... When was that?... Oh dear.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Oh dear.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Call her back--tell her to head for the hospital.  Tell the hospital to expect her.  I'll leave right now.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Look--I'm sorry--I have to go.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: We'll miss you so.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Look--this isn't my apartment, and there isn't anybody else here.  Mrs. Ryan won't be home for a while.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Oh, oh, oh--I thought it was your apartment.  You seemed at home here.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I'm a neighbor.  I have the apartment across the hall.  I have to go to the hospital now.  An emergency.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I mean--I can't leave you here. You'll have to go.  I'll tell Mrs. Ryan you were here.  You can come back later.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Ahh--then she's still alive.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: She's fine.  Please--

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And still Mrs. Harold Ryan?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Will you please go?  An emergency!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: She still has just the one child-- the boy?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Yes!  Yes!  The boy!  One boy!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And what, exactly, is your relationship to Mrs. Ryan?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Neighbor!  Doctor!  I live across the hall.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And you come into Mrs. Ryan's apartment as often as you please, looking into various health matters?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Yes!  Please!  You've got to get out right now!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Just her neighbor and doctor? That's all?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: And her fiancé!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And her fiancé!  How nice.  I hope you'll be very happy--or is that what one says to the woman?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I've got to run!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You wish the woman good luck, and you tell the man how fortunate he is.  That's how it goes.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I've literally got to run!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I won't try to keep up with you. I'm not as fast on my feet as I once was.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Safe and sound, I see.  Oh--you came back.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I came back.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: How was the emergency, Doctor? Profitable, I hope.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: A policeman delivered the baby in a taxicab.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Tough luck.  You'll have to split the fee.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Are--are you crying, Penelope?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: She's crying because she's so happy.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I feel the same way.  What next?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What next?  You leave promptly, of course.  There is no question as to whose home this is--

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: None.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Whose son this is, whose wife that is.  A fiancé is the most ridiculous appurtenance this household could have at this time.  Good night.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Ah!  You're ambulatory!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What a brilliant diagnosis!

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Well now--what seems to be the trouble with the patient today?  A touch of malaria, perhaps?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I know malaria.  Malaria isn't caused by the bites of bats.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: You've been bitten by bats?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Colonel Harper and I once shared a treetop with a family of bats. There was a flash flood.  There were piranha fish in the water. That's how Colonel Harper lost his little toe.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: You have chills?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Chills, fevers, sweats.  You can describe it and name it after yourself: "the Woodly galloping crud."

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You can also describe its cure. I'm eating its cure.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I was going to ask.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Pacqualinincheewa root.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Would you say that again?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Pacqualinincheewa root.  Means "cougar fang." Cures anything but a yellow streak down the back.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I've never heard of it.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Congratulations.  By crossing twenty-eight feet of cockroach- infested carpet, you've become the third white man ever to hear of it.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Are you've seen it work cures?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Hundreds.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Wasn't that sweet of me?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: More and more we find ourselves laying aside false pride and looking into the pharmacopoeias of primitive people.  Curare, ephedrine--we've found some amazing things.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: We have, have we?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: That's an editorial we, of course. I haven't turned up anything personally.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Everything about you is the editorial we.  Take that away from you, and you'd disappear.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Good Lord.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I can just hear the editorial wee- wee-weeing when Looseleaf and I start flying in pacqualinincheewa root.  I can hear the Alice-sit-by- the-fires now: "We discovered it in the Amazon Rain Forest.  Now we cure you with it.  Now we lower our eyes with becoming modesty as we receive heartfelt thanks."

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I thought she was a widow.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You were wrong, you quack!

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I'm going to have to report you to the Department of Health.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Quarantine, possibly.  You may be suffering from a loathsome disease which the American people could do without.  Goodbye.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It died for your sins.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: This little corpse is intended as a lesson?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: There's a certain amount of information there.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Lest we forget how cruel you are.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: This is man to man.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: It's healer to killer.  Is that the same thing?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What brought you back?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: The same hairy, humorless old gods who move you from hither to yon. "Honor, " if you like.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: He's a champion after all. WOODLY Of the corpses and cripples you create for our instruction--when all we can learn from them is this: how cruel you are.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: There's going to be no bloodshed here.  I know how he'll fight--the only way he can fight: with words. The truth.  Am I correct?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I can defeat him with anything from flavored toothpicks to siege howitzers.  But he got it into his little head that he could come here and demolish Harold Ryan with words. The truth!  Correct?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Correct.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What an hallucination!  Oh, dear, dear, dear, dear.  Oh dearie me.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: You haven't heard me yet.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You intend to crack my eardrums with your voice?  Will I bleed from my every orifice?  Who will clean up this awful mess?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: We'll find out now, won't we?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: You're a filthy, rotten bastard.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Oooooo.  That hurt.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: You're old--so old.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Now who's being cruel?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: A living fossil!  Like the cockroaches and the horseshoe crabs.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: We do survive, don't we?  You're going to have to apologize, of course, for calling me a bastard. That's a matter of form--not allowing you or anybody to call me a bastard.  No rush about that. Just remember to apologize sometime soon.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: You're a son of a bitch.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yes--well--uh--that's another one of those statements which more or less automatically requires an apology.  Whenever you feel like it. It's sort of like turning off an alarm clock that's ringing loudly. Your apology turns off the alarm.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I haven't told you, Harold, how comical I think you are.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Comical?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Hands and knees, you say?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And terror, if you don't mind.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You're in one hell of a jam.  You realize that?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I'm high as a kite.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Glands.  You're supposed to be happy when you die.  Call me comical again.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: You're a clown.  You're a clown who kills--but you're a clown.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I love you!  Have a cigar!

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Evolution has made you a clown-- with a cigar.  Simple butchers like you are obsolete!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'm to be left behind--in primordial ooze?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: If you're at home in the ooze, and nowhere else.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: This is going to become very physical.  Are you prepared for that?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: You're not such a creature of the ooze that you'd hurt an unarmed man.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'm an honorable clown?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: King Arthur.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You hope.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: In any event, I will not beg for mercy.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No quarter asked.  No quarter given.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Don't you laugh even inwardly at the heroic balderdash you spew?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Cut me open.  Find out.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I've struck my blow.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: With spittle?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I've poisoned you. HAROLD  Lucretia Borgia?  Something I drank or touched?  You refused a cigar.  That's it! Potassium cyanide in the humidor! Treacherous lover of peace!

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I put a poisoned thought in your head.  Even now that poison is seeping into every lobe of your mind.  It's saying, "Obsolete, obsolete, obsolete," and, "Clown, clown, clown."

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Poison.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: You have a very good mind, or I wouldn't have come back.  That mind is now asking itself, cleverly and fairly, "Is Harold Ryan really a clown?" And the answer is, "Yes."

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I--I really must congratulate you. Something is happening in there.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: You can never take yourself seriously again!  Look at all the creatures you've protected us from! Did you shoot them on the elevator, as they were on their way up here to eat us alive?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No. WOODLY The magic root you gave me--I had it analyzed.  It was discovered by a Harvard botanist in 1893!  He explored your famous jungle for five years, armed with nothing but kindness, a talent for languages, and a pocketknife.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: You aren't going to hurt me.  You aren't going to hurt anybody any more.  Any violent gesture will seem ridiculous--to yourself!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Don Quixote.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: My violin is avenged!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Something seems to have happened to my self-respect.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: And the hell with it.  It was so tragically irrelevant, so preposterously misinformed.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: The new hero is you.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I hate crowds, and I have no charisma--

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You're too modest.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: But the new hero will be a man of science and of peace--like me. He'll disarm you, of course.  No more guns, no more guns.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Was I ever of use?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Never.  For when you began to kill for the fun of it, you became the chief source of agony of mankind.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Here.  Finish the job.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I'm utterly satisfied.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You're making a mistake.  Obsolete old carnivores like me are most dangerous when wounded.  You've wounded me.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: More clowning!  Don't you see?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: We never quit fighting until we're dead.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: You'd be killing a friend.  Don't you know how much I like you?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'm going to shoot you now.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: My self-respect is gone--and my soldier's honor with it.  It is now very easy for me to shoot an unarmed man.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: New dignity can be yours--as a merciful man.  You can change!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Like the saber-toothed tiger.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Oh God--you're really going to kill me. HAROLD It won't hurt as much as the sting of a bumblebee.  Heaven is very much like Paradise, they say. You'll like it there.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Can I beg for mercy--on my knees?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: If you want to be found that way.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: What is this thing that kills me?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Man, as man was meant to be--a vengeful ape who murders.  He will soon be extinct.  It's time, it's time.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Don't shoot.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I've enjoyed being man.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: No.  No.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Get up.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Have it your way.  We'd both be better off dead now.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Can't do it.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Thank God. HAROLD Crawl home.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Thank you--for my life.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: It's trash now, like mine.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: New lives begin!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Somewhere in this city.  Not here, not here.  Tell Penelope I loved her--in my clownish way.  And Paul. Tell him to be a healer, by all means.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Use the sanitary facilities, if I may.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Leave the rifle here.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'll put it in Paul's room, where it belongs.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Give me your word of honor that that's all you're going to do.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: For what it's worth now, Harold Ryan, the clown, gives his sacred word.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Jesus--I dunno.  You know.  What the heck.  Who knows?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Colonel Harper, retired now, dropped an atom bomb on Nagasaki during the Second World War, killing seventy-four thousand people in a flash.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I dunno, boy.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You don't know?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: It was a bitch.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Thank you.  You can leave now.  We'll begin.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: And you went home unannounced, too?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I dunno.  Yeah!  Yeah!  Yeah!  I did.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Alice got married again.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: She did?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You didn't even find that out?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: There was so much going on.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: She married an accountant named Stanley Kestenbaum.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: So that's it! "Kestenbaum, Kestenbaum." Everybody was yelling "Kestenbaum, Kestenbaum." I thought it was some foreign language.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Dead!

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Jesus.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Alice is dead?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: No, no--shit no.  Excuse me, Penelope.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: For saying "shit." Or is that okay now?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Who's dead?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: My mother-in-law.  Fire engines, pulmotors, doctors, cops, coroners--

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Well--I walked up to the front door. I was still alive.  Big surprise. I rang the doorbell, and old Mrs. Wheeler answered.  She had her Goddamn knitting.  I said, "Guess who?" She conked right out.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: How horrible.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: Yeah--cripes.  I never did get any sense out of Alice.  She found me holding up the old lady, dead as a mackerel.  It was a bitch.  You know--maybe Mrs. Wheeler was going to die then and there anyway, even if I'd been the paper boy.  Maybe not.  I dunno, boy.  That's civilian life for you.  Who knows what kills anybody?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: And you, Colonel?  Let me guess: You don't know.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I dunno.

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: So long, you guys.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: What will you do, Colonel?

turns.speaker: LOOSELEAF
turns.text: I dunno.  Marry the first whore who's nice to me, I guess.  Get a job in a motorcycle shop.  So long, you guys.

turns.speaker: WANDA JUNE
turns.text: Mr. Ryan just borrowed my birthday cake.  I don't really know him.

turns.speaker: MILDRED
turns.text: Thought you were another wife, maybe.

turns.speaker: WANDA JUNE
turns.text: I'm only ten years old.

turns.speaker: MILDRED
turns.text: That's what he wanted--a ten-year- old wife.  He'd come home from a war or a safari, and he'd wind up talking to the little kids.

turns.speaker: WANDA JUNE
turns.text: Won't you please join our club? Please?

turns.speaker: MILDRED
turns.text: Honey--Alcoholics Anonymous takes all the time I've got--and Harold Ryan is an individual I would rather forget.  He drove me to drink.  He drove his first two wives to drink.

turns.speaker: VON KONIGSWALD
turns.text: Aha!  Hello!  You're Mildred, right?

turns.speaker: MILDRED
turns.text: I heard you were looking for me.

turns.speaker: VON KONIGSWALD
turns.text: You were Harold Ryan's third wife. Right?

turns.speaker: MILDRED
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: VON KONIGSWALD
turns.text: You want to join the Harold Ryan Fan Club?  Wear a pink jacket with a yellow streak up the back?

turns.speaker: MILDRED
turns.text: Do I have to?  Who's the little girl?

turns.speaker: VON KONIGSWALD
turns.text: Because he was cruel?

turns.speaker: MILDRED
turns.text: Premature ejaculation.

turns.speaker: VON KONIGSWALD
turns.text: Ach soooooooooo. MILDRED No grown woman is a fan of premature ejaculation.  Harold would come home trumpeting and roaring.  He would the kick the furniture with his boots, spit into corners and the fireplace.  He would make me presents of stuffed fish and helmets with holes in them. He would tell me that he had now earned the reward that only a woman could give him, and he'd tear off my clothes.  He would carry me into the bedroom, telling me to scream and kick my feet.  That was very important to him.  I did it.  I tried to be a good wife.  He told me to imagine a herd of stampeding water buffalo.  I couldn't do that, but I pretended I did.  It was all over--ten seconds after he'd said the word "buffalo." Then he'd zip up his pants, and go outside, and tell true war stories to the little kids.  Any little kids.

turns.speaker: VON KONIGSWALD
turns.text: That is sad.

turns.speaker: MILDRED
turns.text: Is it?  I have this theory about why men kill each other and break things.

turns.speaker: VON KONIGSWALD
turns.text: Ja?

turns.speaker: MILDRED
turns.text: Never mind.  It's a dumb theory.  I was going to say it was all sexual..but everything is sexual...but alcohol.  Peace.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: She's my date tonight.  What do you want her to do--bring the poor old jaguars back to life with a bicycle pump?  Bugger off!  Ask Paul what he thinks.  Your mother looks beautiful--right?  Kid?  Doesn't your mother look nice?  Paul?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I don't care what she wears.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Something's made you sore.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Don't worry about it.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: You bet I'll worry about it.  I said something wrong?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's my father's birthday--that's all.  That's all.  Who cares about that?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: I had not the slightest inkling.  Why didn't you say so?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: She doesn't care!  She's not married any more!  She's going to have fun!  I hope you have so much fun you can hardly stand it.  Dr. Woodly--I hope you make up even better jokes about my father than the ones you've said so far.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Kid--kid--

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: And I wish you'd quit touching me all the time.  It drives me nuts!

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Don't!

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: You sure misunderstood something-- and we'd better get it straight.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Explain it to them.  I'm bugging out of here.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Don't touch me.  Get out of the way.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Men can touch other men, and it doesn't mean a thing.  Haven't you ever seen football players after they've won the Superbowl?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: I worship your father.  That stuffed alligator your mother gave me--the one he shot?  It's the proudest thing in my apartment.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Everybody talks about how rotten kids act.  Grownups can be pretty rotten, too.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Thank God!

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: What a relief!

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: That goes double for me.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I don't want to live any more.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: I feel like I want to yell my head off--just yell anything.  Bulllllllllllllll-dickey!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'll kill myself.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: The wife of Harold Ryan is going to marry a pansy next?  This is the end of Western Civilization as far as I'm concerned.  You must be crazy as a fruitcake.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Don't touch me.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Wouldn't you rather have your mother marry me than him?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: All my dreams have suddenly collapsed.  We did have a lot of laughs together, Penelope.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: And this is my son, Paul.  He was only four years old when his father disappeared.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: He's coming back, Mom!  He's the bravest, most wonderful man who ever lived.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I told you this was a simple-minded play.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Maybe he'll come back tonight! It's his birthday.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Stay home tonight!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Oh, Paul--

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You're married!  You've already got a husband!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: He's a ghost!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: He's alive!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Not even Mutual of Omaha thinks so anymore.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: If you have to go out with some guy--can't he be more like Dad?  Herb Shuttle and Norbert Woodly-- can't you do better than those two freaks?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Thank you, kind sir.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: A vacuum cleaner salesman and a fairy doctor.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: A what kind of doctor?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: A fairy--a queer.  Everybody in the building knows he's a queer.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: That's an interesting piece of news.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You're the only woman he ever took out.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Not true.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Still lives with his mother.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You know she has no feet!  You want him to abandon his mother, who has no husband, who has no money of her own, who has no feet?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: How did she lose her feet?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: In a railroad accident many years ago.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I was afraid to ask.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Norbert was just beginning practice. A real man would have sold her to a catfood company, I suppose.  As far as that goes, J. Edgar Hoover still lives with his mother.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I didn't know that.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: A lot of people don't.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: J. Edgar Hoover plays sports.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I don't really know.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: To only exercise Dr. Woodly ever gets is playing the violin and making that stupid peace sign.  Peace.  Peace.  Peace, everybody.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I hate that thing.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's beautiful.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Where will you be?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Anywhere but here.  I'd just sit here and cry about the way my father's been forgotten.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Are you and Dr. Woodly engaged?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Who have you been talking to?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What difference does that make?  Is Dr. Woodly going to be my father now?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Yes, he is.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Aaaaaaaaaaaaaah!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Is Norbert still here?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Then who flushed the toilet?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Father's friend.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: What's his name?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Don't know.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: For Heaven's sakes!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Mom?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: That man is your father.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: There stands the loins from which you've sprung.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I don't get it.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: It is you, isn't it, Harold?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: That's why I'm crying.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Dr. Woodly?  You know who this is?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: What are his symptoms?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Shivers and sweats and groans.  His teeth chatter.  What'll we do?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: What does he say to do?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: He can hardly talk.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: It is an emergency, isn't it?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Then get him.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Peace, everybody--Paul, Penelope.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You're taking Mom out tonight?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: You're going out?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: We don't have a maid any more.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Everything stays as it is!

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: A monument to a man who thought that what the world needed most was more rhinoceros meat.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: My father!

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I apologize.  But you didn't know him, and neither did I.  How's your asthma?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Don't worry about it.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: How's the fungus around your thumbnail?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's fine!

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: It's jungle rot!  This room is making everybody sick!  This is your family doctor speaking now.  Here--I brought you something else to hang on your wall, for the sake of variety.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I hate that thing.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Keeps fairies away!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It came yesterday.  I haven't opened it yet.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Maybe it's supposed to end now. Maybe God wouldn't have it any other way.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I didn't get his name.  A friend of your father?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: He isn't any friend of Father.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: He isn't?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: He is my father.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Please--

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: He's not anybody to tell somebody else what to do in a master bedroom.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I'll get ready, Herb.  I didn't expect you this soon.  Please--won't everybody be nice to everybody else while I'm gone?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: I keep having this nightmare--that he catches us.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Doing what?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: He'd kill me.  He'd be right to kill me, too--the kind of guy he is.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Or was.  We haven't done anything wrong, you know.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: He'd assume we had.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: That's something I suppose.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: All through the day I'm so confident.  That's why I'm such a good salesman, you know?  I have confidence, and I look like I have confidence, and that gives other people confidence.  People laugh sometimes when they find out I'm a vacuum cleaner salesman.  They stop laughing, though, when they find out I made forty-three thousand dollars last year.  I've got six other salesmen working under me, and what they all plug into is my confidence.  That's what charges them up.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I'm glad.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: I was captain of the wrestling team at Lehigh University.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: If you want to wrestle, you got Lehigh.  If you want to play tennis, you go to Vanderbilt.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I don't want to go to Vanderbilt.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: You don't wrestle if you don't have supreme confidence, and I wrestled. But when I get with you, and I say to myself, "My God--here I am with the wife of Harold Ryan, one of the great heroes of all time--"

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Something happens to my confidence.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: This conversation took place, incidentally, about three months before Harold was declared legally dead.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: When Harold is definitely out of the picture, Penelope, when I don't have to worry about doing him wrong or you wrong or Paul wrong.  I'm going to ask you to be my wife.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I'm touched.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: That's when I'll get my confidence back.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: If you'll pardon the expression, that's when you'll see the fur and feathers fly.  Good night.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Coming.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Women are always late.  You'll find out.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Gentlemen!  Is this right for a fight?  It's been so long.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Beautiful!  I've never seen that coat.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Seven jaguars' skins, I'm told. Harold shot every one.  Shall we go?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: What then?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: We could have had some kind of birthday party for him.  We could have taken Paul to the fight with us.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Did you see him?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Is he all right?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Far as I know.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Is he coming home?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: He ditched me.  He started running, and I started running, then he lost me in the park.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: The park!

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: It's dark in there. PENELOPE And that's where he is!

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: I figure he ducked in one place and ducked out another.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You figure!

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Then I saw this bakery store that was still open, so I bought a birthday cake.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: A what?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: For Harold.  When Paul comes home, we can have some birthday cake.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: How nice.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: They had this cake somebody else hadn't picked up.  It says, "Happy Birthday, Somebody Else."

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Did you talk to Paul?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Before he started to run.  He said his father carried a key to this apartment around his neck--and someday we'd all hear the sound of that key in the door.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: We've got to find him.  I want you to show me exactly where you saw him last.  And you stay here, Norbert, in case he comes home.  That's all he said--the thing about the key?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: He said one other thing.  It wasn't very nice.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: What was it?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: He told me to take a flying fuck at the moon.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: What's the matter now?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: We got a birthday cake, kid.  Did you see the cake?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Possibly.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: How long has this been going on?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: A week.  We were waiting for the right time to--

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: I feel as though I had been made a perfect chump of.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Marry me instead.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Thank you, Herb.  You're a wonderful man.  You really are. Everybody respects you for what you've done for scouting and the Little League.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: You're saying no.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I'm saying no--and thank you.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: I didn't make my move fast enough. That's it, isn't it?  I was too respectful.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You were wonderful.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: What's so wonderful if I lost the sale?  You poor kid.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: It's true.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Well--it was nice while it lasted. Thanks for the memories.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You and Harold are friends?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: He's the most wonderful guy I ever met, Penelope.  He's the most complicated guy I ever met.  I can't believe it, but he's going to take me to Africa with him.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I am Dr. Norbert Woodly--a physician, a healer.  I find it disgusting and frightening that a killer should be a respected member of society.  Gentleness must replace violence everywhere, or we are doomed.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Would you like to say something about killing, Colonel?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Herb Shuttle is taking me to a fight.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Take plenty of cigars.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: We made the date three months ago.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I must take you to an emergency ward sometime--on a Saturday night. That's also fun.  I came to see Selma, as a matter of fact.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: She quit this afternoon.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: The animals made her sneeze and cry too much.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I'm glad somebody finally cried. Every time I come in here and see all this unnecessary death, I want to cry.  I don't cry, of course.  Not manly, you know.  Did she try antihistamines?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: They made her so sleepy she couldn't work.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Throw out all this junk.  Burn it! This room crawls with tropical disease.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: "War is not healthy for children and other living things." How lovely.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: No doubt Paul thinks it stinks.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Oh no!  Wear a coat of cotton--wear a coat of wool.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Wear a coat of domestic mink.  For the love of God, though, Penelope, don't lightheartedly advertise that the last of the jaguars died for you.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I never knew when to hold it--or who to ask, or what to say.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Tonight's the night.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: This is very good for us.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: It is?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: The wilder Paul is tonight, the calmer he'll be tomorrow.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: As long as he keeps out of the park.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: After this explosion, I think, he'll be able to accept the fact that his mother is going to marry again.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: The only thing I ever told him about life was, "Keep out of the park after the sun goes down."

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: We've got to dump Shuttle.  He brings his vacuum cleaner on dates?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: That's the XKE.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: The what?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: It's an experimental model.  He doesn't dare leave it in his car, for fear it will fall into the hands of competition.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: What kind of a life is that?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: He told me one time what the proudest moment of his life was. He made Eagle Scout when he was twenty-nine years old.  Oh, Norbert--promise me that Paul has not gone into the park!

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: If you warned him against it as much as you say, it's almost a certainty.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: No!  Oh no!  Three people murdered in there in the last six weeks! The police won't even go in there any more.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I wish Paul luck.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: It's suicide!

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I'd be dead by now if that were the case.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Meaning?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Every night, Penelope, for the past two years, I've made it a point to walk through the park at midnight.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Why would you do that?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: To show myself how brave I am.  The issue's in doubt, you know--since I'm always for peace--

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I'm amazed.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Me, too.  I know something not even the police know--what's in the park at midnight.  Nothing.  Or, when I'm in there, there's me in there. Fear and nobody and me.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: And maybe Paul.  What about the murderers?  They're in there!

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: They didn't murder me.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Paul's only twelve years old.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: He can make the sound of human footsteps--which is a terrifying sound.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: We've got to rescue him.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: If he is in the park, luck is all that can save him now, and there's plenty of that.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: He's not your son.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: No.  But he's going to be.  If he is in the park and he comes out safely on the other side, I can say to him, "You and I are the only men with balls enough to walk through the park at midnight."  On that we can build.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: It's a jungle out there.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: That's been said before.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: He'd go to a movie.  I think that's what he'd do.  If I were sure he was in a movie, I could stop worrying.  We could have him paged.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You know each other?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: We met here earlier this evening.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: How neat.  How keen.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Thank you.  Thank you very much.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: I believe in miracles now.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I'm taking her to the airport a few minutes from now.  She's going to East St. Louis--to visit an aunt.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Tell her to have a nice trip.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Get out of here.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: It's really that bad?

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You fool, you fool.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Oh--look at the poor, crucified violin, would you?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Everything's going to be beautiful.

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: You fake!  You're no better than the dumbest general in the Pentagon.  You're not going to beat Harold. You're not going to beat anybody. You're not going to stay here, either--yammering and taunting until you're most gloriously killed. Go home!

turns.speaker: PENELOPE
turns.text: Do it!

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Goodbye.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Hi kid.  Would you look what the car dragged in.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: I'm glad you brought your vacuum cleaner.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Is that a fact?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: That maid just quit.  The place is a mess.  You can start in the master bedroom.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: You've got to fight from time to time.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Not true.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Or get eaten alive.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: That's not true either--or needn't be, unless we make it true.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Phooey.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Which we do.  But we can stop doing that.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: We simply stop doing that--dropping things on each other, eating each other alive.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Penelope!  We're late!

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: The late Mrs. Harold Ryan.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: I'm sick of this argument.  I just have one more thing to say: If you elect a President, you support him, no matter what he does.  That's the only way you can have a country!

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: It's the planet that's in ghastly trouble now and all our brothers and sisters thereon.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: None of my relatives are Chinese Communists.  Speak for yourself.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Chinese maniacs and Russian maniacs and American maniacs and French maniacs and British maniacs have turned this lovely, moist, nourishing blue-green ball into a doomsday device.  Let a radar set and a computer mistake a hawk or a meteor for a missile, and that's the end of mankind.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: You can believe that if you want. I talk to guys like you, and I want to commit suicide.  You get that weight-lifting set I sent you?

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Start with the smallest weights. Every week add a pound or two.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Maybe God has let everybody who ever lived be reborn--so he or she can see how it ends.  Even Pithecanthropus erectus and Australopithecus and Sinanthropus pekensis and the Neanderthalers are back on Earth--to see how it ends. They're all on Times Square--making change for peepshows.  Or recruiting Marines.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: You ever hear the story about the boy who carried a calf around the barn every day?

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: He died of a massive rupture.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: You think you're so funny.  You're not even funny.  Right?  Right?  You don't hurt yourself if you start out slow.

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: You're preparing him for a career in the slaughterhouses of Dubuque?  Take care of your body, yes!  But don't become a bender of horseshoes and railroad spikes.  Don't become obsessed by your musculature.  Any one of these poor, dead animals here was a thousand times the athlete you can ever hope to be. Their magic was in their muscles. Your magic is in your brains!

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: Kid--kid--

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: It's good.  Let him go.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: If he'd just come out for the Little League, the way I asked him, he'd find out we touch all the time--shove each other, slug each other, and just horse around.  I'm going to go get him--

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: Don't!  Let him have all the privacy he wants.  Let him grieve, let him rage.  There has never been a funeral for his father.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: If he'd just get into scouting, and camp out some, and see how everybody roughhouses around the fire--

turns.speaker: WOODLY
turns.text: What a beautiful demonstration this is of the utter necessity of rites of passage.

turns.speaker: SHUTTLE
turns.text: I feel like I've been double- crossed.  If you'd just told me it was Harold's birthday--
